Tomato_healthy.description: The tomato plant is healthy, with green leaves and no visible signs of infections or damage. It shows normal growth and development.
Tomato_healthy.solution: No action is required. Maintain regular watering, fertilization, and pest control to keep the plant healthy.

Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot affects pepper plants, causing small, dark, and water-soaked lesions on leaves and fruits. Severe infections can lead to leaf drop and reduced yield.
Pepper__bell___Bacterial_spot.solution: Use copper-based fungicides, avoid overhead watering, and practice crop rotation. Remove infected leaves to prevent further spread.

Tomato_Late_blight.description: Late blight is a fungal disease that causes large, irregular, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits. It can spread rapidly in cool, moist conditions.
Tomato_Late_blight.solution: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper. Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent spreading. Increase plant spacing for better air circulation.

Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) leads to mottling, mosaic patterns, and deformation of leaves. Infected plants show reduced growth and fruit quality.
Tomato__Tomato_mosaic_virus.solution: Remove infected plants immediately and disinfect gardening tools. Control insect vectors such as aphids to prevent transmission. Avoid handling plants unnecessarily.

Tomato__Target_Spot.description: Target spot causes small, circular lesions with concentric rings on leaves, leading to premature defoliation and reduced yield.
Tomato__Target_Spot.solution: Use fungicides like azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil. Ensure proper spacing and ventilation to reduce humidity. Remove and destroy infected leaves.

Pepper__bell___healthy.description: The pepper plant is healthy, with no signs of bacterial or fungal infections. Leaves are vibrant green and fruits develop properly.
Pepper__bell___healthy.solution: Continue routine care, including appropriate watering, fertilization, and pest management. Monitor for any changes in plant health.

Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot causes small, circular brown spots with gray centers, leading to premature leaf drop and weakened plant vigor.
Tomato_Septoria_leaf_spot.solution: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Remove and destroy infected leaves. Space plants adequately to promote air circulation.

Tomato_Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold thrives in humid environments, causing yellowing of leaves and the formation of mold on the underside, which can lead to defoliation.
Tomato_Leaf_Mold.solution: Reduce humidity around the plants, provide adequate ventilation, and apply fungicides to control the spread. Remove affected leaves promptly.

Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.description: Spider mites cause stippling and webbing on leaves, resulting in yellowing and eventual leaf drop. Severe infestations can stress the plant significantly.
Tomato_Spider_mites_Two_spotted_spider_m.solution: Spray neem oil or insecticidal soap to control spider mites. Increase humidity levels and introduce natural predators like ladybugs if possible.

Tomato_Bacterial_spot.description: Bacterial spot on tomatoes causes water-soaked spots on leaves and fruits, leading to blemished produce and reduced yields.
Tomato_Bacterial_spot.solution: Use copper-based bactericides and practice crop rotation. Remove infected plants and avoid overhead irrigation to reduce spread.

Potato___Early_blight.description: Early blight in potatoes causes brown spots with concentric rings on leaves, eventually leading to leaf drop and reduced tuber production.
Potato___Early_blight.solution: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or mancozeb. Remove infected leaves and ensure proper plant spacing to reduce humidity.

Tomato_Early_blight.description: Early blight in tomatoes causes small, brown lesions on leaves and stems, leading to defoliation and weakened plants.
Tomato_Early_blight.solution: Use preventive fungicides and maintain good garden hygiene. Remove infected leaves and ensure proper plant spacing to improve air circulation.

Potato___healthy.description: The potato plant is thriving with healthy, dark green foliage and no signs of infection or stress. It shows normal growth and tuber development.
Potato___healthy.solution: Continue regular watering, fertilization, and pest management. Monitor the plant regularly for any signs of disease.

Potato___Late_blight.description: Late blight in potatoes leads to water-soaked, dark lesions on leaves and stems, followed by rapid plant collapse in humid conditions.
Potato___Late_blight.solution: Use fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper hydroxide. Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent further spread.

Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.description: Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) causes upward curling and yellowing of leaves, stunting plant growth and reducing yield.
Tomato__Tomato_YellowLeaf__Curl_Virus.solution: Remove infected plants immediately and control whiteflies, the primary vector of TYLCV. Use reflective mulch to repel insects and prevent virus spread.
